abstract: This week, the Appraisal takes stock of a Brooklyn street where town houses are bookended by public housing projects in a neighborhood where property values have risen sharply over the years.
snippet: This week, the Appraisal takes stock of a Brooklyn street where town houses are bookended by public housing projects in a neighborhood where property values have risen sharply over the years.
lead_paragraph: New York is famously a city of contrasts: old frame houses butt up against new construction, ethnicities commingle on the subway, the moneyed live in view of the poor. This week the Appraisal takes stock of a Brooklyn street where this is particularly true: Warren between Nevins and Bond in Boerum Hill, where town houses are bookended by two public housing projects in a neighborhood where property values have risen sharply over the years.

headline.main: Quaintness Tucked Between Brooklyn Housing Projects
